roleset.name: (cause to) be cloudy, becoming cloudy
roleset.note: CLOUD-V NOTES: Frames file for 'cloud' based on sentences in wsj. No Verbnet entry. (from cloud.01-v)

CLOUDING-N NOTES: Expanded by Julia based on BOLT, WN eventive noun lexicon, cloud.01. VNcls other_cos-45.4 corresponds, for some reason, to 'clouded', but I assume it is supposed to be 'cloud', and applies here either way. (from clouding.01-n)

example.name: cloud-v: agentive, sorta
example.text: This can have its purposes at times, but there's no reason *trace* to cloud the importance and allure of Western concepts of freedom and justice.
example.arg: the importance and allure of Western concepts of freedom and justice

example.name: cloud-v: instrumental subject
example.text: ``The New York Stock Exchange has vested interests'' in its big member securities firms ``that *trace* cloud its objectivity,'' Mr. Timbers said.

example.name: cloud-v: all args
example.text: John clouded his senses with heavy doses of children's cough syrup
example.arg: with heavy doses of children's cough syrup

example.name: clouding-n: all args; actual cloud
example.text: And with that he resumed his clouding the room with his foul-smelling smoke.

example.name: clouding-n: args 0, 1; metaphorical
example.text: Reid had been struggling with enough demons without his clouding the issue.

roleset.name: occluded (with clouds or cloudiness)
roleset.note: CLOUDY-J NOTES: Added by Julia based on SHARP-SRED (from cloudy.01-j)

example.name: cloudy-j: causer with adjective
example.text: Raoul oreno was crouched next to her, his dark eyes cloudy with concern.
